newsitem.title: CHINA: Market goes on rollercoaster ride in Hong Kong.
newsitem.headline: Market goes on rollercoaster ride in Hong Kong.

text.p: Hong Kong's stock market went for a rollercoaster ride on Thursday, the first day of trading since the capitalist enclave was returned to China.
The Hang Seng Index, which had closed at a record high last week as the curtain fell on British rule, leaped by more than one percent to 15,363.61 points at the start of trading.

But then the index promptly succumbed to profit-taking and dipped back down again amid fears over government plans to increase housing supply in one of the world's most overcrowded cities. Property stocks led the market down.
Hong Kong, shaking off its party hangover after five days of non-stop celebrations, was back doing what it does best -- making money and lots of it.
With financiers around the world watching closely to see how Hong Kong would fare under China's "one country, two systems" formula for reunification, new leader Tung Chee-hwa had plenty to celebrate.
And he hammered home the message to Hong Kong's top executives at a big dinner on Wednesday night.
"We are finally masters of our own destiny," he told them. "Our goal is clear: we must make Hong Kong more successful than before," he said.
Tung, a shipping magnate hand-picked by Beijing to steer Hong Kong through uncertain waters, was eager to reassure any nervous investors.
"The Central Government (Beijing) have given us a free hand in dealing with our internal affairs and have demonstrated flexibility, understanding, cooperation and accommodation."
Hong Kong's economy has risen by almost six percent a year over the past decade and a bullish Tung warned the naysayers: "No one has ever betted against Hong Kong in the past and won."
The sunny outlook for the economy was certainly not matched by the weather. One person was feared dead and eight were injured in landslides caused by days of torrential rain.
All schools were closed across Hong Kong, roads were blocked and weather forecasters warned there were more storms to come.
The caretaker at a Buddhist monastery was feared dead after an avalanche of mud and rocks enveloped her house, police said.
Eight people were rescued after being buried under tonnes of mud while trying to clear an earlier landslide.

Superintendent Lee Chiu-Keung, who suffered a broken leg, said from his hospital bed: "My eyes, my ears and my nose were all filled with mud and I felt my right leg go. But I told myself to stay calm."
Chris Patten, Britain's 28th and final governor who left early on Tuesday after a tearful and emotional farewell, could be back within a year.
Media reports said Patten, already given a hefty advance for the book he is now writing, could front a major television series on Asia.
Patten's agent, Michael Sissons, told the South China Morning Post he was optimistic the series would go ahead.
Asked if that meant Patten returning to Hong Kong, Sissons said: "Absolutely, you bet."
